video.title: Learn C Programming with Dr. Chuck (feat. classic book by Kernighan and Ritchie)
video.description:
In this complete C programming course, Dr. Charles Severance (aka Dr. Chuck) will help you understand computer architecture and low-level programming through studying the "classic" version of the C Programming language from the 1978 book written by Brian Kernighan and Dennis Ritchie.

In this course we will be reflecting on how C provided an important foundation for the creation of modern programming languages. This is not a good place to start if you do not already have some programming experience. A suggested pre-requisite is Dr. Chuck's Python for Everybody course: https://youtu.be/8DvywoWv6fI

📖 Online C Programming book by Brian Kernighan and Dennis Ritchie: https://www.cc4e.com/book/chap00.md
🔗 Additional course resources: https://www.cc4e.com/
(Unlock Code Hint: View the developer console on the website.)

✏️ Dr. Charles Severance developed this course. He is a professor at the University of Michigan and one of the most popular software instructors in the world.

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Course Intro
⌨️ (0:03:09) Chapter 0: Introduction
⌨️ (0:20:44) Chapter 1: A Tutorial Introduction
⌨️ (1:59:17) Chapter 2: Types, Operators, and Expressions
⌨️ (3:02:09) Chapter 3: Control Flow
⌨️ (3:49:31) Chapter 4: Functions and Program Structure
⌨️ (5:20:32) Chapter 5: Pointers and Arrays
⌨️ (6:50:30) Chapter 6: Structures
⌨️ (8:16:33) Chapter 7: Input and Output
⌨️ (9:02:02) Chapter 8: The UNIX System Interface

topLevelComment.author: Ronald L. Johnson
topLevelComment.text: i have the 1988 release of the Kernighan and Ritchie C programming language. at one point i owned the original 78 release but this second edition brings standards into the equation via ansi-c and i personally would recommend learning from this edition. it's the book i learned the basics of c in the mid to late 80's, with the very important nuances included by the creator/s of the language. it's an excellent book to learn the basics of c. this book prepares you to use c reference guides proficiently once you understand the syntax and control structures of the language. i can't stress how important it can be to learn c from this single book. it is a bit terse, assumes much however if you know the basics of the unix os, know how to us it's various editors (i still do all my c coding in vi) and the compiler subsystem, literally half the battle is won.

topLevelComment.author: Werner Roets
topLevelComment.text: It's just beautiful design isn't it. The prolog/C style syntax is still so dominant today. I've only really worked with high level languages and it seems a shame that we just push the cost onto the consumer. I think web browsers area a great example. Web applications are easy to build but incredibly inefficient. Very little consideration is given to the memory consumption.

topLevelComment.author: Josue Ramirez
topLevelComment.text: I am so glad videos like this exist. The tough part is actually getting through them and absorbing the material.

replies.author: Ronald L. Johnson
replies.text: and the best way to do that is copy all the code and run it as you go through the book. each chapter builds on the previous with TONS of repetition. the repetition drills the syntax and functions into you and by the end of the book you have it all memorized. you will not learn c by simply reading the book. you need to type in all that code, compile, run etc etc. this book will not make you a master c programmer, whatever that is, but it will make you a proficient c programmer. it readies you for the next book, intermediate c programming which i HIGHLY recommend as the natural progression in mastering c.

topLevelComment.author: wil Montreal21
topLevelComment.text: Is there not a licence problem (like music) reading and showing an entire book on youtube?

replies.author: Dean G
replies.text:
There are certainly are copyright problems in some countries about Photocopying books. It's debatable whether there is a copy right issue here, but given the book is so old and hardly anyone buys a copy these days, I doubt it is worth the authors pursuing a copyright infringement.

In fact any decent C programmer owns a copy of this book as a reference book (I do) which is frequently used when writing a C program: it is indispensable. This video is more likely to generate sales of the book! So probably not in the interests of the authors to claim a copyright infringement.

topLevelComment.author: Krzysiekoy
topLevelComment.text:
I mean... I like dr Chuck but what is the point of reading the whole book VERBATIM including the CODE SYNTAX...

This is like having to listen to a 9 hour lecture where the professor reads off of huge wall-of-text slides verbatim. You can parse the slide with our eyes / in your mind in about few seconds, but then have to wait for prof. to read the slide out loud for the next 3 minutes...

When I saw this announcement from freecodecamp, I thought this is going to be more of a commentary - going over the book, giving insights, providing explanations, and NOT just reading the whole thing verbatim. This is honestly so bizzare...

This whole thing looks absolutely superfluous... Like if you see a snippet of code, then you can quickly parse it in your head. Having the code read out loud character-by-character is nothing but distracting. I would understand talking about the code and explaining what it does, but reading it verbatim?

- pound define underscore n file
- type def struct underscore iobuff
- open square bracket...

????

What is the point of this whole thing? What am I missing?

replies.author: D3F3KT
replies.text: Yeah, very strange that the top comments are praising the instructor and the video. Once I saw what is was all about I stopped watching. Perhaps this only appeals to audio book listeners. I had to scroll down several lines in order to spot constructive criticism on this "video". Then I went on to watch an actual tutorial instead of this garbage.

replies.author: Yojan Shrestha
replies.text: I genuinely thought this was an audio book based on the way this was presented. And no clue why others are praising for the content when it is abysmal for the YT format.

topLevelComment.author: J

topLevelComment.author: Joe Yoest
topLevelComment.text:
Am I missing something here? I spot checked several points in this video and it seems like he’s literally just reading K&R C from cover to cover. Doesn’t look like he’s even writing, compiling, and running the code, let alone providing any instructional content. 

It seems like this is a flat-out ripoff of K&R - just recording their book in audio form isn’t the same as creating a course featuring their book. 
I’ve watched some fcc Python courses and they were very well done; I’m wondering if this instructor has ever written a line of C code.

topLevelComment.author: Artyom Mart
topLevelComment.text:
Is information in this course relevant?
Does it use the old version of C?

replies.author: Dean G
replies.text: It I recall correctly C++ compilers will still compile C code.

replies.author: echristopherson78
replies.text: One nice thing is that it appears Dr. Chuck gives lots of notes on the text that at least touch on some of the differences between K&R C and ANSI C, in relevant places.

replies.author: echristopherson78
replies.text: It uses the first edition (1978) of the book, which teaches what's known as K&R C (as opposed to ANSI C). Someone recently told me that he prefers the first edition because it teaches you more about being close to the machine and not using the "training wheels" that he perceived ANSI C to have. That said, within C coding, K&R C is extremely old and not often used anymore in its purest form.

replies.author: Dean G

@silmar pinheiro C is not theoretical. It's simply a language and you use whatever elements of it you need.

It is fairly low level compared to other high level languages.

replies.author: Computer Science and Careers

replies.author: silmar pinheiro
replies.text:
This book is theoretical. So this course is basically theoretical. No updates, this book is decades old.
That being said. C is very theoretical, it's close to the metal so you have to know what is a pointer and why strings are pointers, etc.

replies.author: Chuck Severance
replies.text: This is intended as a read of the book with commentary.  There will also be a full course - that is coming.  The idea is that you can sit back, relax, and listen like an audio book.   The concepts in C are pretty dense and for some folks - the ability to listen to the book (and code) while on a bus or in a car - and listen over and over will allows complex concepts to sink in.  One of the problems I face as a professor is that students don't read the book - this is my attempt to solve that by reading it to them audio-book style.

replies.author: this is really me
replies.text: While the example code is outdated, and several functions are now considered unsafe for use, the actual text and insights are timeless. Read the book, skip the code.

replies.author: Chuck Severance
replies.text: Not really.  This is about how the world changed in 1978 - and since most people won't really write in C - this book is focused at looking at how C changed the world and how C is the cause of our modern computing environment - both hardware and software.
